title: Arrival of sound
brief_description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. Actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the ‘Talkie Terror’, but when Don Juan and The Jazz Singer debuted, there was no turning back.

constellations_primary.name: Significant sounds
constellations_primary.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.
